slides.title: Our Mission
text_content: Our Mission

At The Giving Garden, our mission is to unlock the potential of willing and able labor and unused corporate green space while enhancing a sense of fulfillment for those who are cognitively challenged. While many would view our source of labor as incapable or unwilling, we believe engaging the cognitively challenged will allow them to feel self fulfilled and also potentially alleviate the burden on our public welfare system.
The Giving Garden -  240 Bald Hill Road, Warwick RI, 02886

slides.title: Our Goal
text_content: Our Goal

Our goal is to give people with cognitive challenges a chance to give back through gardening. The cognitively challenged clients are able to utilize the undeveloped land provided by the partnership to grow produce with the goal of donating the crop yield to a community food bank.
The Giving Garden -  240 Bald Hill Road, Warwick RI, 02886

slides.title: Potential Economic Impact
text_content: Potential Economic Impact

By donating fresh local produce to the Rhode Island Food Bank we can help begin to solve a major economic problem our state faces.
Healthy diets reduce morbidity and mortality and produce many kinds of economic benefits: lower medical care and institutional care costs, higher productivity, improved quality of life, and increased life expectancy. 

A governmental study estimates that healthier diets in the United States would annually prevent $70.9 billion in medical costs, lost productivity, and the value of premature deaths associated with four health conditions: CHD, cancer, stroke, and diabetes.
The Giving Garden -  240 Bald Hill Road, Warwick RI, 02886

slides.title: Steps to run a successful garden
text_content: Steps to run a successful garden

1.	 Mark It Out
Make your new garden the best it can be. Give it a fun shape with flowing curves or use it to echo the lines of your house. Get it just right by laying out a hose to outline your bed. Once you have the perfect shape, mark the edges with a line of sand or flour.
2.	Get Rid Of Grass and Weeds
If you have grass growing in your new garden spot, dig it up with a spade or sod cutter. Or, if you have time to wait, mow that area as low as you can, then cover it with a several-sheet-thick layer of newspaper and several inches of soil or compost. Wait a couple of months for the grass to die.
The Giving Garden -  240 Bald Hill Road, Warwick RI, 02886

slides.title: Steps to run a successful garden
text_content: Steps to run a successful garden

3.	Dig It Up!
Now comes the digging. Dig up or till your new garden, removing any rocks, roots, or other debris. If you have poor soil, now's also a great time to incorporate organic matter, such as compost. Just dig it in while you work the ground.
4.	Site Your Plants 
Though it takes a little extra time, placing all your plants before you put them in the ground can make a world of difference. This allows you to get the spacing just right and make your plants really will look good next to each other.
The Giving Garden -  240 Bald Hill Road, Warwick RI, 02886

slides.title: Steps to run a successful garden
text_content: Steps to run a successful garden

5.	Get Planting!
When you know all of your plants are in exactly the right spots, plant them in the ground. It's helpful to loosen or tease the plants' roots before you put them in the ground, especially if they were rootbound.
6.	Spread Mulch
Other than amending the soil, the best thing you can do to keep your new garden healthy and low-maintenance is to spread mulch. A 2-inch-deep layer of shredded wood or other material will do wonders for stopping weeds and helping your soil conserve moisture during times of drought.
